UK hiring slowing - BoE to cut again next year

The outlook for hiring still looks bleak and as real wage growth starts to take a significant hit from higher inflation, we think markets are underpricing the risk of 2017 BoE easing.

11:07 am
PM

There are still clear risks ahead for the UK labour market and we may be starting to see early signs of a more sustained fall in hiring in today’s jobs report. The “headline” 3M/3M change in employment fell by more than expected to 49k (from 106k). This partly reflects a strong “single month” figure in June dropping out of the moving average. But it is hard to ignore the fact that hiring has taken a noticeable turn following a run of strong numbers just prior to the referendum. Survey measures of hiring intentions continue to point to a significant slowdown over coming months as firms respond to heightened uncertainty following Brexit.

The other key metric in this report – wage growth – remained resilient. Excluding bonuses, average weekly earnings increased by 2.4% YoY. To a certain extent, this has been helped along by the impact of the introduction of the National Living Wage earlier this year. But weaker economic activity hits wage growth with a lag, so today's resilient numbers probably still reflect stronger activity in 2015/early 2016.

Crucially though, real wages have been, and will continue to be, hit by higher inflation. We expect headline inflation to move above 3% in 2Q17 and with pay increases likely to be moderated given the weaker hiring environment, this drag on real wages could start to dampen consumer spending and sentiment next year.

We think that markets are under-pricing the risk of further BoE easing in the first half of next year, despite their recent shift to a neutral bias. We forecast a 15bp rate cut in May on the expectation that economic data will start to deteriorate and uncertainty will remain heightened, particularly around the time when Article 50 is expected to be triggered.

TBH I'm usually confused. My confusion irritates me, and I go in with the irritation rather than the confusion. Today, though, I can't even get irritated.

BE

BE

Although we are not aware of the details, we have been assured by Morrisons that they acknowledge and respect the exclusivity provisions in our agreement, which oblige Morrisons to operate their online grocery business only through the Ocado arrangements. Meanwhile we are making good progress wOCDith development of the Erith CFC, which we will operate for ourselves and for Morrisons.com, and with the creation of a store-pick solution for Morrisons.com."

11:12 am

11:14 am
BE

BE

Once I do you'll be first to know. Currently, I'm just confused. My state is confusion.

BE

Let's see if the sellside can clear it up any. Here's Shore, Morrison's shop broker.

11:15 am
PM

Well, they'll argue that it's off line at the Morrisons end of the Amazon deal, but it's a breach of the spirit of the Ocado/Morrisons deal, taht's for sure

BE

Commencing forthwith, Morrison will supply and pick for Amazon Prime customers, orders to be delivered by Amazon, commencing in a selected postcodes in London and Hertfordshire. The supply agreement will utilise Morrisons' existing store network and will be consistent with the group's ambition to expand in a disciplined and capital light manner.
We believe this announcement suggests that Morrisons' initial experiences with Amazon (and vice versa) have been encouraging, whilst the store based retailer's broader ambitions and capabilities online appear to be extending; a sentiment that may not be so warmly welcomed by Messrs. Steiner & Co., at Ocado^ (OCDO, Hold at 275p); we reiterate that this is a tie-up that links Amazon Prime customers to Morrisons" offer and so is separate from Morrisons.com, albeit Ocado's shares could react negatively to this news.

BE

A matter of convenience
The main emphasis of the commercial initiative, for which there is no financial information, is to provide Amazon Prime customers access to the majority of the Morrison's offer in a convenient manner. The proposition will be called 'Morrisons at Amazon'. For a charge of £6.99 Prime customers will gain access to an order within one hour, whilst there is no charge for an order within a later two hour slot. As such, it is a new dimension that extends, deepens and enables Amazon's online capabilities in the convenience market whilst doing the same for the Morrisons brand in many respects too.
We also point out that with its low market share and especially shallow reach in London and the South East, through Amazon Prime customers, the Morrison brand can gain welcome extension. If successful, this arrangement should help store volumes, so leverage, whereas the initial agreement utilised Morrison factory and distribution centre to service Amazon's facilities. Depending upon the price file, this initiative could bring strong value credentials to Amazon's fresh and food-2-go offering in time; noting the many millions of customers the American domiciled group has in the UK. Furthermore, if successful, it could also catapult Morrison's access to the convenience market where it has no physical presence.

11:16 am
BE

No change to forecasts at this time...
Following this announcement, we are not adjusting forecasts for Morrisons. However, what we do point out is that the extension of this agreement bodes well for the ongoing wholesaling activities of the group, so bolstering the capability of management to deliver on its aspiration of £50-100m of additional PTP to emerge from profit streams outside the corn chain.

BE

(@roddy1234, @Pharma: that's a funny definition of exclusivity. One could say it's the opposite.)

BE

... but more resilience is being injected into the medium-term
As such, we feel that with a continuation of sound core chain (i.e. supermarket) activity, there is a firming basis for Morrison to meet and maybe even beat our medium-term PTP expectations; for FY2018 we forecast CPTP of £356m, solid growth on our FY2017 forecast of £330m. With more robust profitability we believe Morrisons has growing scope to further deleverage, generate visibility into a rising dividend (covered 2.0x by EPS) and even consider further shareholder friendly initiatives.

11:17 am
BE

Modern day superstore entrepreneurs
Lastly, this announcement further underscores the high level of entrepreneurship that CEO, David Potts CBE, and CFO Trevor Strain, are bringing on a progressive and sustained basis to Morrisons. A number of interesting trials have commenced that demonstrate a commendable skill in better utilising the group's assets, supporting medium-term growth and doing so in a demonstrably capital light/high return manner. HOUSE STOCK.

BE

And Credit Suisse .........

BE

We believe the strategic impact of this agreement is significant. From an industry perspective, it continues the shift to online, but in a unique way – this customer is part of the Amazon ecosystem, which has been effective in extending its reach into areas well beyond general merchandise. The immediacy of delivery is a step change to the broader existing online grocery market, and has the potential to disrupt the main drivers of growth in traditional grocery – the convenience store.

11:17 am
BE

For Morrisons, this is a way to extend its channel reach for almost no capital outlay. Without knowing the supply cost details we cannot judge the relative profitability of baskets shopped via different channels, but the return on capital should be very high. We are also unconcerned about cannibalisation; with ~10% market share, it is much more likely that the incremental Amazon customer comes from Tesco, Sainsbury or Asda. It also forges a closer bond between Amazon and Morrisons, which should help allay any fears that Amazon entered the original wholesale supply agreement as a short-term learning exercise only.

BE

Amazon has been searching for the optimal way to pick and deliver groceries for over 7 years. Today's announcement is a hybrid solution, where Amazon's customer management, order processing, database management and delivery logistics can be leveraged. It is evident from the lack of progress that Amazon is still searching for the best solution - something that this agreement helps address. Amazon's traditional warehouses have none of the complex materials handling systems within Ocado's CFCs. Store picking, while inherently inefficient, is a good fit here:
Amazon can learn a great deal, they can "hire" a store network, the solution scales quickly and Amazon is not as driven by the bottom line. At a certain sales density within an area they can transition to centralised operations.

BE

The impact on Ocado is mixed. In the near term, we expect clients to see this as an encroachment into their existing agreement with Morrisons, putting the growth of that channel at risk. Over the medium term, however, we firmly believe that store-pick fulfilment will be superseded by centralised fulfilment. Amazon will either develop or buy that technology, and Ocado has the most advanced, fit for purpose grocery fulfilment system available. We see Ocado as a structural winner, whether it is acquired, or whether Amazon's growth will force others to contract for its technology.

Because of the unfortunate way in which the post-results analysts’ meeting was conducted, we were unable to obtain any further clarity on the opening programme economics.

PM

In our opinion the data presented was internally inconsistent and presented in a positive way that we felt was at variance with overall delivery, which is slowing. We do not expect this matter to be resolved in the near term as investors are presented with data which is in our view in-conclusive.

PM

There was no disclosure nor discussion on the recent upsurge in rent, which we would argue is the cost of capital in this business, and little new in areas where it would be unrealistic to expect the company to have significantly better visibility than anyone else, such as the impact on consumer demand patterns for the likely upsurge in imported inflation in calendar 2017. But in areas like sterling’s impact on buying costs, we felt that reassurance on the current year when the impact, if it comes, will be in the following financial year was unhelpful.

We have made very minor recasts to our assumptions and forecasts here. Opex for now is running ahead of sales growth as both LFL continues muted and lower performing new stores become more significant in the overall business mix.

We have held our Sell recommendation and our Fair Value at 190p reflecting principally DCF.

B&M delivered H1 results in-line with market expectations and reiterated full
year guidance. The company demonstrated similar or improving sales
momentum, good control of margins, and strong cashflow. These strong
cashflows suggest the company will pay another special dividend next year.
Another 10p special would imply the stock yields 6.2%. The company is
demonstrating its ability to grow its profits rapidly in a challenging
environment. Trading on CY17 P/E of 16.8x, or a PEG of 1.2x, and with long
term growth potential in the UK and Germany, we reiterate our Buy rating

PM

Ticking several boxes ...
Investors have had a number of concerns about B&M in recent quarters. We
discussed some of these in “Some familiar debates”, 27 October. These
concerns have included: [1] slowing like-for-like sales growth: though
cannibalisation is fading, the underlying is improving, and a period of softer
comps is ahead; [2] UK consumer demand: management showed consumer
patterns have not yet since the EU referendum; [3] Gross margins: though
B&M offset c.100bps of currency pressure in H1 as gross margins rose; [4] The
new store pipeline slipping: but management’s guidance was robust (for 50 in
FY Mar-18). Currency and pricing remains a debate for next year, but modest
inflationary pressures could strengthen B&M’s price leadership credentials.
... and maintaining guidance.
Space roll-out guidance has been maintained (at least on a sq footage basis),
stable gross margin guidance has also been maintained, and cost leverage
should improve in H2. For FY Mar-17 our Adj EBITDA of £222m is unchanged.
Target remains 300p, reiterate Buy rating
Although we do not explicitly model it, management’s balance sheet policy
implies another special dividend is likely to be paid at year end. A 10p special,
maintaining leverage, implies a total potential dividend yield of 6.2%. On
unchanged forecasts our DCF-based target price remains 300p. The DCF model
uses a WACC of 8.9% (RFR 4.5%, ERP 4.5%, beta 1.0x) and nominal TGR of
+2.0%. B&M trades on calendarised 2017E P/E of 16.8x. Downside risks
include negative leverage from slowing LFLs, challenges finding new store
space, or a loss of grocery price leadership

BE

Morrisons recently renegotiated its contract with Ocado to allow Morrisons to do store picking. However, we had assumed that Ocado would be building the infrastructure to allow them to do this and the service would be deployed in areas where Ocado's distribution network doesn't reach (the far South West and North East of England). As such, the move by Morrisons is a surprise.

We doubt the announcement will do a lot for Morrisons shares today; it sits as part of the previously announced 'medium term' GBP50-100m PBT opportunity and short term, is likely to be modest. It does, to our minds, undermine Ocado’s aspirations to find a new partner however.

Barratt Developments this morning released an update on trading since the beginning of
its financial year (July). Market conditions remain healthy, and the company has seen a
net private sales rate of 0.74 since the beginning of July. This is ahead of the 0.7 rate
seen during the same period last year. Forward sales have increased significantly, with
the wholly-owned (ex-JV) order book +19.5% year-on-year, volume +13% and ASP
+5%. As previously flagged by the company, JV sales will decline markedly in FY2017;
this is evident in the order book, which has fallen by 61% compared to the same period
last year.

BE

High-end London market shows further signs of weakness Key financials (£m)
Higher price points in London have again been singled out as an area of weakness, with
the company recently lowering prices at sites in this area. Sales rates have also been
flagged as a drag on the overall sales rate. In an attempt to mitigate the risk of further
weakness, Barratt has entered an exchanged build and sale agreement for 39 apartments
for a total consideration of £47m. Despite this concern, the company remains focused on
the delivery of its 20% gross margin target for FY2017 (Davy: 19.5%).

BE

High-end London continues to be the main area of concern
from a trading perspective for Barratt as well as the wider
sector. Outside of this area, the market is surprisingly robust,
and sales growth is continuing into the end of the year. Overall,
it seems that the recent good momentum at the business
should continue at least for FY2017.

Gulf Keystone (GKP LN – 1.15p) – (HOLD – $203 – 519mm; 0.65 – 1.66p) – Wrong Focus: Today's announcement isn't really a surprise, but it isn't the right thing to do, not yet anyway. The smaller shareholders have supported the Company through a significantly trying period, and for shareholders holding less than 100 shares to see such an albeit significant destruction in value, essentially reduced to nil, will gall some. However, and we need to be frank here, the alternative was nil for all shareholders had the conversion not happened. While we can appreciate that the management want to separate themselves from the past and move forwards, but given that past, and the lingering debt that remains, we think that the number of shares in issue should be the least of their worries. What will change investors' perception of the Company is delivery and free cash flow generation. Our valuation range remains $203 – 519mm, 0.65 – 1.66p using the current shares in issue, but post the share consolidation the per share valuation range will be 65 – 166p. Reiterate HOLD

"Energy Efficiency to Cut Electricity Demand and Earnings," is the headline. Damn energy efficiency. Messing up investor portfolios.

11:52 am
BE

In the context of rising inflation and falling household disposable income, we believe consumer-facing service businesses, such as those of Centrica, will see tough times ahead. Increasing energy efficiency is also likely to drive lower energy demand in the long term. Furthermore, we see a real risk that the government will intervene and impose structural changes to the way retail markets operate, which we think will drive down margins and increase competition. Within this context, we believe Centrica’s current strategy to reduce costs can only go so far to protect margins. As a result, we are downgrading Centrica to Sell, with a revised target price of 175p.

undefined
PM

Footsie drifting again

11:54 am
PM

Can't help but agree with Joe W this morning...

PM

Yesterday in this space we were talking about financial stocks in the Trump era. Investors have piled into them, ostensibly due to a combination of a steeper yield curve - which is good for banks' profit margins - and a potential rollback of regulations. One risk that investors may not be thinking about, however, is what happens to the business of banking in a de-globalized world, with fewer cross-border deals and a diminished need to hedge. Of course, that's just one risk to big banks under Trump. Check out this transcript, posted by Buzzfeed, of a 2014 speech given by Steve Bannon, who has been tapped as Trump's Chief Strategist. In the speech he slams the fact that no bank bosses faced criminal charges and that nobody had their bonuses or equity taken away. Elsewhere he says that he considers the "Ayn Rand" school of capitalism to be disturbing. It's certainly possible that this will have no relevance on the Trump administration. However as Charles Robertson, the global chief economist of Renaissance Capital, said on TV yesterday (around the 27 minute mark), "we're trading on very light news" and there may be more "surprises" still to come. In other words, it may behoove everyone to have a little less conviction in their narrative right now.

That's from the Bloomberg foward guidance email

11:57 am
BE

After five years of underperformance, the standout performing sector of 2016 has been mining. The FTSE350 Mining index is up 103% (in GBP) while highly leveraged names like Anglo American and Glencore are up 292% and 213% respectively. The story of how 2016 unfolded can be told in four points: 1) improving debt market conditions on higher oil; 2) China credit stimulus; 3) supply cuts in key commodities such as coal (China) and zinc (Glencore); and 4) deleveraging impact of higher cashflows on equities.
The key question is, where to next?
And the answer is challenging. Investors are faced with a difficult task – looking at stock performance charts, justifiable rallies in some commodities such as met coal which seem based on physical tightness and others such as copper which seem to be a consequence of a “catch-up” trade and a rotation to hard assets following the US election.

BE

Our thesis: Focus on the more compelling commodity stories with more deleveraging to come We have been late to recognise the strength and duration of this rally but with this note make some notable upgrades. Our thesis is investors should focus on 1) the stocks with highest exposure to commodities where the rally is more fundamental and 2) that have the highest potential for further deleveraging from here.
Based on this thesis we upgrade Vedanta Resources (VED.L) to Buy from Neutral and add it to the Conviction List (zinc exposure and significant deleveraging). We also upgrade Anglo American (from Sell), Lundin (from Neutral) and Kumba (from Neutral) to Buy.

Vedanta Resources PLC (VED:LSE): Last: 795.50, up 35.5 (+4.67%), High: 804.50, Low: 784.50, Volume: 382.52k
11:58 am
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,102, up 5.5 (+0.50%), High: 1,130, Low: 1,087, Volume: 3.40m
BE

There is a dichotomy for investors in our approach and upgrades. Based on our numbers and consensus, miners are not pricing in spot, yet are cheap on our normalized set of commodity prices in 2018E once the deleveraging year of 2017E has been taken into account. The concern for investors is as met and thermal coal and iron ore roll off from their recent highs towards our normalized levels, will the stocks underperform with the decline in commodity prices, even if they screen cheap on the lower commodity prices? This is difficult to answer and is certainly a major risk in our upgrade of Anglo American and Vedanta here. If commodities were to remain at this level it would just be a question of time before equities began to price towards spot, in our view.
